awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Elucidation of the mechanistic origins of plasmon-induced chemical reactions
awd_abstract_narration:
With this CAREER Award, the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the Division of Chemistry is supporting Professor Prashant Jain of the University of Illinois to study the detailed manner in which light energy is converted into chemical energy within metallic materials. This process, if properly understood and controlled, may become a candidate technology for capturing solar energy and for driving energy-intensive processes in the chemical industry with light. Professor Jain aims at preparing strongly light-absorbing materials that can efficiently convert sunlight into chemical energy in fuels.  Another effort involves the achievement of light-to-chemical energy conversion using cheaper, more abundant materials. Alongside the laboratory efforts, an interactive software tool is being developed and employed for the purpose of education on the interaction of light with matter. The educational program is aimed at generating early scientific interest in the classroom by means of vivid, hands-on examples from optics, preparing high school, undergraduate, and graduate students for future science and technology careers. Outreach activities seek to foster community  awareness of solar energy as a clean, renewable alternative to energy from fossil fuels.
 
Professor Jain investigates the physicochemical mechanism(s) by which the plasmonic excitation of a noble metal-containing heterostructure induces or catalyzes chemical reactions on the surface of the nanostructure. In this project, a plasmonic heterostructure consisting of Au nanoparticles in contact with a semiconducting oxide (titanium dioxide and zinc oxide) is studied for determining the relative contributions of plasmonic near-field enhancement, hot electron transfer, and photothermal heating in photocatalytic reactions. This research aims to elucidate the mechanistic role of the oxide and assess whether near-field-assisted bandgap or sub-bandgap photoexcitation of carriers in the oxide is responsible for the observed photoactivity, or, whether charge separation across the metal/oxide is a more important contributor.  Professor Jain uses single-molecule fluoresence to identify whether the photoreaction takes place on the metal, on the semiconducting oxide, or at the metal/oxide interface. Finally, he explores plasmon excitation-induced photocatalysis in a noble metal-free plasmonic oxide, which represents an interface-free system where plasmonic excitation and semiconductor electronic transitions are localized within the same crystallite.

por.por_cntn:
Laboratories across the world have found that shining light on metal nanostructures, specifically those made of gold, silver, and copper, triggers chemical reactions on their surfaces. Prior to this work, the underlying origin of this phenomenon was not well understood. Prof. Jain of the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign (UIUC) was awarded this grant for investigating the mechanisms by which light energy is converted into chemical energy on metallic nanostructures.

In the course of the project, principal investigator Jain and his research group found that the photoexcitation produces energetic electron-hole pairs within the nanoparticles. In aqueous solutions, this energetic state persists on the nanostructure in the form of a charge polarization, and it lowers the energy barrier for redox chemical reactions occurring on the surfaces of the nanostructures. Not only does this effect accelerate such reactions but it also facilitates reactions that require multiple electron and protons, such as the conversion of carbon dioxide, a greenhouse gas, to fuels and the green synthesis of ammonia, a promising hydrogen carrier. The research also showed that energetic electron-hole pairs generated by photoexcitation can provide the driving force for reactions that are otherwise thermodynamically unfavorable. In addition to the role of charge carriers, Prof. Jain elucidated the role played by nanoparticle heating that invariably results from light excitation and showed how this effect can be appropriately managed. Lastly, Prof. Jain synthesized novel plasmonic and semiconducting nanostructures and explained their electronic structures and optical properties, which are relevant for light-harvesting and energy-conversion processes. The findings and advances from the project have been reported in 24 publications.

The scientific understanding brought about by this work will propel the use of metal nanostructures in technologies and devices for the capture of sunlight and the use of solar energy for the sustainable manufacturing of chemicals and fuels, industrial processes for which are energetically demanding and highly carbon emissive. The work was accompanied by an educational and outreach program: an interactive software toolkit (nanoDDSCAT and nanoDDSCAT+) was developed in collaboration with the NSF-funded nanoBIO node at UIUC. This toolkit is enabling undergraduate and graduate students with little expertise in electrodynamics to conduct computer simulations and design of light-absorbing nanostructured systems and devices. The toolkit hosted on nanoHUB has over a 1000 users and more than 800,000 simulations have been conducted using it. In addition to enabling research, this toolkit equips students with optics and computational modeling skills for future careers in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics.

Through the work, graduate students, including a Latino American and several women researchers, acquired know-how in catalysis, surface science, materials synthesis and processing, spectroscopic analysis, and computational modeling, all critical needs in the United States research and development workforce. The project provided research opportunities for two undergraduate women from the Chemistry program at UIUC and prepared them for their ongoing graduate studies. The research also involved postdoctoral scholars in various capacities, who developed skills and expertise in these areas and received opportunities to mentor graduate and undergraduate students and manage a research group. Three postdoctoral scholars who participated in this research have launched their own research groups.
